title: The Epidemiology of Scabies
text: Scabies neglected tropical disease caused infestation skin microscopic mite (Sarcoptes scabiei). Symptoms characterized itchiness rash site infestation. Scabies affects around 400 million people per year, accounts large proportion skin disease many low- middle-income countries1. rise scabies cases observed Europe recent years2–7, putting pressure local health services. [Elaborate?] Despite considerable burden scabies poses annually, little known disease dynamics scabies transmission, incubation time (time exposure symptom onset), generation time (time infection index case secondary case), serial interval (time onset symptoms index case time symptom onset secondary case), growth rate, reproduction number (average number secondary cases resulting one index case). 1944 study Mellanby8 forms much basis current understanding scabies transmission; however, study carried small number healthy volunteers may representative natural history scabies populations scabies widespread. important results Mellanby include… [Add key results Mellanby 1944: curve mites time, time symptom onset, probability transmission secondary objects] work, aim estimate epidemiological characteristics scabies. critical better understand underlying disease dynamics scabies 1) assess current spread 2) inform infection control policy. modelling work performed study potential impacts intervention strategies, mass drug administration, scabies transmission9–11; however, values used parameterise models based largely Mellanby’s 1944 study use information mite life-cycle approximate quantities latent period infectious period. However, information doesn’t necessarily provide good estimates transmission potential humans. example, Kinyanjui et al.9 assume latent period 7-14 days allow time time takes fertilised female mite reproduce incorporate susceptible-exposed-infectious model scabies transmission. However, assumes equal chance infectiousness despite number mites inhabiting infested indivual. Mellanby8 shows probability onward transmission scabies rare number mites individual low increases mite population grows. better approximation disease process can obtained using generation time serial interval; however, estimates exist scabies. Additionally, growth rate reproduction number quantities describe fast infectious disease spreads. also used determine appropriate control measures reduce number secondary infections epidemic dies . However, case scabies, basic reproduction number, average number secondary infections resulting one index case completely susceptible population, never described. makes immensely difficult determine level control measures needed contain disease spread. evidence continues suggest scabies growing problem European countries remains large problem elsewhere, important describe epidemiological characteristics scabies required control efforts curb scabies epidemics can determined. study, use epidemic curves scabies outbreaks literature estimate serial interval. use data weekly scabies cases Netherlands estimate time-varying reproduction number annual growth rate. [sure intro]

title: The Epidemiology of Scabies
text: used reported symptom onset dates cases previously published studies scabies outbreaks (Table @ref(tab:data_sources_table)) estimate serial interval scabies. original study data provided, reconstructed data published epidemic curves.

title: The Epidemiology of Scabies
text: Using dates symptom onset scabies cases six different studies scabies outbreaks (Table @ref(tab:si_results_tab)), estimated mean standard deviation serial interval distribution using method proposed Vink et al.12. method involves calculating index case--case (ICC) interval person, person greatest value number days since symptom onset considered index case. rest individuals ICC interval calculated number days symptom onset index case. assumed Normal serial interval distribution. performed sensitivity analysis Gamma distribution assumed serial interval distribution [TODO!]. also performed Bayesian meta-analysis using brms package R13 estimate pooled mean serial interval. used Bayesian hierarchical random-effects model. chose use random effects model assume study “true” serial interval, sampled overarching distribution true serial intervals14. specified prior distribution N(100, 50) true pooled mean Cauchy(0,1) -study heterogeneity. performed sensitivity analyses choices prior distributions [TODO!].

title: The Epidemiology of Scabies
text: estimated annual growth rate scabies cases fitting exponential growth model annual incidence scabies per 1000 people 2011 2023 Netherlands15. Using fitted exponential growth model estimated growth rate, determined projected incidence scabies per 1000 people 2033 interventions implemented. used bootstrapping 1000 samples obtain 95% confidence bounds projected incidence scabies per 1000 people.

title: The Epidemiology of Scabies
text: obtained weekly reported cases scabies 2011 2023 Netherlands2,15. performed spectral analysis time series weekly scabies cases using modified Daniell kernel (m = 2) smoothing identify typical frequencies within time series. estimate time-varying reproduction number, first randomly assigned reported case date symptom onset week case reported. Using daily time series, applied method proposed Wallinga Teunis16 estimate time-varying reproduction number determining likelihood event occurring every pair time points17. method requires specification serial interval distribution. assumed Normal serial interval distribution mean 91.2 standard deviation 22.79, estimated previously. obtain confidence intervals daily reproduction number, used bootstrapping. analyses performed R 4.4.018.

title: The Epidemiology of Scabies
text: estimated mean standard deviation serial interval using epidemic curves study (Table @ref(si_results_tab)). [Figure epidemic curves!] considerable variation studies largest estimated mean serial interval 167.34 (SD = 9.72) data Kaburi et al.19 describes outbreak preschool Ghana. smallest estimated mean serial interval 16.11 (SD = 2.42), estimated data Larrosa et al.20 describes outbreak hospital Spain. Estimated mean standard deviation (SD) serial interval distribution, days, study. Study Details Mean SD Reference Kaburi et al. 2019 Outbreak scabies preschool Ghana 167.34 9.72 [@kaburi2019] Ariza et al. 2013 Outbreak scabies preschool Germany 98.40 8.54 [@ariza2013] Akunzirwe et al. 2023 Outbreak scabies fishing community Uganda 122.92 26.92 [@uganda] Tjon-Kon-Fat et al 2021. Outbreak scabies nursing home Netherlands 110.71 16.14 [@tjon-kon-fat2021] Larosa et al. 2003 Outbreak scabies hospital Spain 16.11 2.42 [@larrosa2003] Division Public Behavioral Health 2015 Outbreak scabies long-term care facility USA 21.92 15.24 [@nevada] obtain pooled estimate mean serial interval, performed Bayesian meta-analysis random intercepts study. estimated pooled mean serial interval 91.20 (95% CI: 45.84, 138.04) (Figure @ref(fsi_multi-plot)B). saw individual study estimates (Table @ref(si_results_tab)), meta-analysis provided evidence substantial heterogeneity among studies due large value standard deviation random intercepts (60.7). large variation mean serial interval estimates can visualised plotting estimated distributions study’s serial interval shown Figure @ref(si_multi-plot). normal distribution assumed, parameterized estimated mean standard deviation serial interval study.  Estimated serial interval distributions using data epidemic curves different scabies outbreaks. B) Forest plot estimated mean serial interval pooled mean.

what: Growth Rate and Basic Reproduction Number
title: The Epidemiology of Scabies
text: estimated annual growth rate scabies cases fitting exponential growth model annual incidence scabies per 1000 people 2011 2023 Netherlands15. estimated annual growth rate 0.353 (95% CI: 0.152, 0.452). Using fitted exponential growth model estimated growth rate, determined projected incidence scabies per 1000 people 2033 interventions implemented. found substantial increase scabies incidence next 10 years Netherlands measures taken mitigate scabies spread (Figure @ref(fig:growth_rate_fig)). [TODO] Add estimate basic reproduction number based growth rate generation time (use mean serial interval). R0 = 1 + (0.353 * 1/b), b generation time days. Scabies incidence per 1000 people 2011 2023 (points) projected scabies indcidence per 1000 people 2024 2033 (line) using exponential growth model annual growth rate = 0.353. Shaded regions represent 95% confidence intervals projected scabies incidence.

title: The Epidemiology of Scabies
text: first performed spectral analysis time series weekly scabies cases Netherlands 2011 2023 using modified Daniell kernel (m = 2) smoothing. found typical frequencies 1/51.4 weeks 1/26.67 weeks (26.67 weeks ~187 days). suggests generation interval 187 days strong annual periodicity. also estimated time-varying reproduction number plotted season. appears peak transmissibility occurs autumn years extend winter (Figure \@ref(rt_plot)). Time-varying reproduction number scabies transmission. Colored bands denote season. Winter = December 1 – February 28 (29 leap year); Spring = March 1 – May 31; Summer = June 1 – August. 31; Autumn = September 1 – November 31. Note: place-holder figure.

what: Convolution of the triangular distribution with the mixture component density (continuous case) — conv_tri_dist
title: Convolution of the triangular distribution with the mixture component density (continuous case) — conv_tri_dist
text: split folded normal distribution Primary-Secondary, Primary-Tertiary Primary-Quaternary routes two parts component 1: Co-Primary route component 2+3: Primary-Secondary route component 4+5: Primary-Tertiary route component 6+7: Primary-Quaternary route

title: Convolution of the triangular distribution with the mixture component density (continuous case) — conv_tri_dist
code: conv_tri_dist(x, sigma = sd(x), r = x, mu = mean(x), route, quantity = "zero")

title: Convolution of the triangular distribution with the mixture component density (continuous case) — conv_tri_dist
text: x vector index case case intervals sigma standard deviation density distribution r description?? mu mean density distribution route integer; 1 7 indicates route transmission. quantity character; "zero", "lower", "upper"

title: Convolution of the triangular distribution with the mixture component density (continuous case) — conv_tri_dist
text: vector density draws value x

title: Convolution of the triangular distribution with the mixture component density (continuous case) — conv_tri_dist

what: Calculate f0 for Different Components — f0
title: Calculate f0 for Different Components — f0
text: function calculates value f0 based component, components represent transmission routes: Co-Primary (CP), Primary-Secondary (PS), Primary-Tertiary (PT), Primary-Quaternary (PQ). split PS, PT PQ routes two parts, component 1: CP route component 2+3: PS route component 4+5: PT route component 6+7: PQ route

title: Calculate f0 for Different Components — f0
Calculate f0 for Different Components — f0
text: x numeric; value evaluate function. mu numeric; mean value. sigma numeric; standard deviation. comp integer; component number (1 7). dist string; assumed distribution serial interval; takes "normal" "gamma"; defaults "normal"

title: Calculate f0 for Different Components — f0
text: calculated value f0.

title: Calculate f0 for Different Components — f0
text: dist = gamma, mean (\(\mu\)) standard deviation (sigma) converted shape (k) scale (theta) parameters gamma distribution, mean (\(\mu\) ) variance (\(\sigma^2\)) given : $$\mu = k \times \theta$$ $$\sigma^2 = k \times \theta^2$$.

what: Compute the likelihood of a transmission pair given the serial interval distribution — get_likelihood
title: Compute the likelihood of a transmission pair given the serial interval distribution — get_likelihood
text: Two distributions can specified serial interval distribution: Normal Gamma. Normal distribution mean \(\mu\) standard deviation \(\sigma\) assumed default. Gamma distribution specified, mean \(\mu\) standard deviation \(\sigma\) converted shape rate parameters Gamma distribution : $$ \beta = \frac{\mu}{\sigma^2} \alpha = \left(\frac{\mu}{\beta}\right)^2 $$

title: Compute the likelihood of a transmission pair given the serial interval distribution — get_likelihood
code: get_likelihood(   serial_interval,   mu,   sigma,   distn = "normal",   tail_cut = NULL,   positive_only = TRUE )

title: Compute the likelihood of a transmission pair given the serial interval distribution — get_likelihood
text: serial_interval numeric; Time difference \( t_1 - t_2 \) (days) two events. mu numeric; mean serial interval distribution sigma numeric; standard deviation serial interval distribution distn string; distribution assumed serial interval. Defaults "normal", also accepts "gamma". tail_cut numeric; number days beyond likelihood transmission two events 0. Defaults NULL. positive_only logical; TRUE, positive serial intervals considered. serial interval negative, function returns 0.

title: Compute the likelihood of a transmission pair given the serial interval distribution — get_likelihood
text: Likelihood transmission pair.

title: Integrate Component Function — integrate_component
text: function integrates component function specified interval.

title: Integrate Component Function — integrate_component
code: integrate_component(   d,   mu,   sigma,   comp,   dist = c("normal", "gamma"),   lower = TRUE )

title: Integrate Component Function — integrate_component
text: d numeric; data point. mu numeric; mean value. sigma numeric, standard deviation. comp integer; component number, accepts values 1 7. dist string; assumed distribution serial interval; take "normal" "gamma". lower logical; indicates whether integrate lower part (TRUE) upper part (FALSE).

title: Integrate Component Function — integrate_component
text: integrated value.

title: Wrapper function to for integrate_components() — integrate_components_wrapper
text: function computes integral components given data point.

Wrapper function to for integrate_components() — integrate_components_wrapper
text: d numeric; data point. mu numeric; mean value. sigma numeric; standard deviation. dist string; assumed distribution serial interval; takes "normal" "gamma"; defaults "normal"

title: Wrapper function to for integrate_components() — integrate_components_wrapper
text: vector containing integrated values component.

title: Wrapper function to for integrate_components() — integrate_components_wrapper
code: # Example 1: Compute integrations for a specific data point integrate_components_wrapper(1, 10, 2) #> [1] 2.626139e-01 1.162059e-05 9.421600e-08 3.458653e-11 2.559163e-13 #> [6] 1.096782e-16 7.867958e-19

what: mitey: Toolkit to Estimate Infectious Disease Dynamics Parameters — mitey-package
title: mitey: Toolkit to Estimate Infectious Disease Dynamics Parameters — mitey-package
text: package provides methods estimate key epidemiological parameters infectious diseases particular application scabies.

title: mitey: Toolkit to Estimate Infectious Disease Dynamics Parameters — mitey-package
text: Maintainer: Kylie Ainslie kylie.ainslie@rivm.nl (ORCID)

title: Estimate Time-varying Reproduction Number — rt_estim
text: function estimates time-varying reproduction number (R_t) using method proposed Wallinga Teunis (AJE 2004). function takes input data frame incidence data requires specification serial interval distribution. user must input mean standard deviation serial interval distribution select functional form: Normal Gamma.

title: Estimate Time-varying Reproduction Number — rt_estim
code: rt_estim(   inc_dat,   mean_si,   sd_si,   dist_si = c("normal", "gamma"),   cut_tail = NULL,   pos_only = TRUE )

title: Estimate Time-varying Reproduction Number — rt_estim
text: inc_dat data frame; data frame incidence data. data frame two columns: inc (daily incidence) date. mean_si numeric; mean serial interval distribution sd_si numeric; standard deviation serial interval distribution dist_si string; distribution assumed serial interval. Accepts "normal" "gamma". cut_tail numeric; number days beyond likelihood transmission two events 0. Defaults NULL. pos_only logical; TRUE, positive serial intervals considered. serial interval negative, function returns 0.

title: Estimate Time-varying Reproduction Number — rt_estim
text: numeric vector expected reproduction number day.

Estimate serial interval using the EM Algorithm as developed by Vink et al. (2014) — si_estim
text: dat vector; numeric vector index case case intervals n integer; number iterations EM algorithm; defaults n = 50 dist string; assumed distribution serial interval; takes "normal" "gamma"; defaults "normal".
